post.author: bpanjavan
post.title: File Upload in Silverlight 2.0
post.content:
There is a small but growing ASP.NET vs. Silverlight debate.  Every IT shop is hesitant to “upgrade” to Silverlight, and for good reason.  Actually, lack of good reason is more precise.  Silverlight offers great streaming media and rich user interface capabilities, the only battles it seems to have won.  To keep searching for more strengths, you have to think about Silverlight’s fundamental architecture.  In reality it’s a mini .NET Runtime engine running on the client side.  It must excel at client intensive operations; one of such is File Uploading.

I present to you a Silverlight 2.0 File Upload demo.  If you’re in a hurry you can find it here.

Here are 3 steps to get you started (A simple app shouldn’t require any more than that)
   

    1. Use the ADD and REMOVE buttons to manage your list of files.  In consideration of my host I draw the line at 300KBs per file.

    2.Select the files you wish to upload and click UPLOAD.  Once again I have to draw the line so I limit no more than 3 files to upload at once

    3. Click any of your files to view.  Use the “BACK” button at the bottom to return to the file list and repeat from Step 1.

Now there’s no denying ASP.NET and plain HTML have the ability to file upload.  But this is done through a very, I repeat VERY restrictive means.  The FileUpload control is restrictive in terms of aesthetics.  I’ve seen countless developers try to custom style this with no avail.  But it’s also restrictive in terms of functionality.  You can select only one file.  If you want to upload multiple files at once, you have to put multiple FIleUpload controls onto the page.  If the user wants to quickly upload their photo album, this is NOT convenient because they have to choose their files one by one by one.  A rudimentary example is Walmart’s original Photo Center.


I compliment them to knowing this and developing a flash application called “Easy Upload”, admittedly even better than what I’ve done so far.


HTML couldn’t do it alone.  Flash allowed them to customize the aesthetics and create a tool that’s not only rich, but very flexible and responsive as well.  Bottom line; this is what Silverlight can do for ASP.NET.

Code to be posted soon…
